div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin April 10, 1916
div1.p:
This camp is a delight after Pau. One is at seemingly perfect liberty and can do about as one pleases. Of course it pleases me to go ahead as fast as I can with my work but when I’m not working I can do what I want and its a great relief. Johnson and Rumsey sneaked into Paris. They are not very serious. All of the fellows who were in the Nieuport school at Pau are still here and so I am with friends. Due to the fact that I’ve had more hours of flight on the Nieuport than most of the men here I shall probably get on the Baby right away. Up
to the present I’ve been kept running from bureau to bureau.

What did you say to the Slades? I was asking a chap here about the blunder I made and he said the Slades didn’t like it that I blamed them for the result. You know I took especial pains to impress Mrs. Slade that it wasn’t her party that had fixed me. I never blamed her — it is of course all my fault. The individual I talked with claimed that I blamed the Slades in a letter to you. I wish you would try and convince Mrs. Slade that she is wrong in thinking I attributed anything to her party.

This place is in the war zone and it takes a ^good three days for letters to come and to go.
The American Escadrille thinks it will leave for the front this week and Kiffin says I can get off with them. I hope so anyway. Otherwise I may have a long wait.
It was delightful to see you again in Paris and I thank you so much for making me feel at ease. I had been afraid of looking you in the face again.

Will you please tell Mary Lines that I’m sorry I had such a short time and could not see her and thank her for writing me about Betty. The first time I go in I shall try my best to see her. I don’t know how to get news now tho [sic] I don’t suppose there is any need of worrying.

A chap burnt up in
a machine here yesterday. His gasoline tank exploded and no one could get to him.

I left the helice in charge of the patron of my little hotel (Hotel Beauvau, 24 Rue Miromesneil) with your father’s name on it but I do not see the need of bothering Monsieur Guerin When I’ll soon be in.

closer.seg:
J.R. Mac Connell, Pilote
Aviation, Division Nieuport
Plessis - Belleville.
